rules.rule: Words ending in '-ant'/'-ent' converts to '-nte'
Words ending in '-ly' converts to 'mente'
Words ending in '-ence'/'-ance' converts to '-cia'
Words ending in '-ary' converts to '-ario'.
Words ending in '-ible'/'-able' are pronounced as 'bleh'
Words ending in '-tion' converts to '-ción'
The first 'R' in a word is usually a rolling 'R'
Double 'r' in a word is a rolling 'r'
There are no words that have a double 's'
'h's are silent unless it is 'ch'
'z's are pronounced as 'th' in Spain or 's' in Latin America
Past tense words have accents at the end
Past tense haber form: 'ar' verbs are replaced with 'ado'

examples.english: We have anticipated it for a long time
examples.spanish: Lo hemos anticipado por mucho tiempo

rules.rule: Past tense haber form: 'ir/er' and replace it with 'ido'
Past tense ongoing action form: 'ar' is replaced by 'aba'. 'I' pronoun uses the same form as 'he', 'she', 'it', 'you' formal pronouns.

examples.english: I was waiting for you (informal) -> I was awaiting you (informal)
I was waiting for you (formal / masculine) -> I was awaiting you (formal / masculine)
We were waiting for you guys (feminine)
They were trying to find it for me -> They were trying to find me it
examples.spanish: Me lo intentaban encontrar -> Intentaban encontrarmelo

examples.english: They were trying to find it for me (explicit)

rules.rule: Estaba + future tense '-ing' form can also be used as a past tense ongoing action form

examples.english: I was taking a Spanish course -> I was taking a course of Spanish
examples.spanish: Tomaba un curso de Espanõl -> Estaba tomando un curso de Espanõl

examples.english: It was for sale (it sells itself). It would be for sale. For sale.
examples.spanish: Se vendía. Se vendería. Se vende

rules.rule: When using '-ing' form as an adjective, the 'ar' changes to 'ante' and 'ir/er' changes to 'iente'

examples.english: The waning moon -> The moon waning

rules.rule: Past tense ongoing action form: 'ir/er' is replaced by 'ía'. 'I' pronoun uses the same form as 'he', 'she', 'it', 'you' formal pronouns.

examples.english: I was eating. I would eat.
I was selling it. I would sell it.
It was for sale (it sells itself). It would be for sale. For sale.
examples.spanish: Se vendía. Se vendería. Se vende

examples.english: I couldn't do it because I didn't have the time. -> I was not able to do it because I did not have the time.
examples.spanish: No podía hacerlo porque no tenía el tiempo

examples.english: We could go -> We were able to go

rules.rule: Present tense words have accents at the second last syllable
Future tense words can use present tense rules if given future context

examples.english: We are going to see her
Are you going to see him soon?
Are you going to see us soon?
Let's speak next week -> Let's speak the week that (it) comes
We see each other -> We see us -> Goodbye
We will see each other next week
examples.spanish: Nos vemos la semana qué viene

rules.rule: Although this is not common, future tense words can be constructed by attaching an accented haber to the end of the verb

examples.english: I will eat (in the future). I have eaten
I will find it (in the future)
He will find them (in the future)
I will stay (in the future) -> I will remain myself
I will stay here (in the future) -> I will remain myself here
I will be tired (in the future)

rules.rule: For 'ar' verbs, you can construct future tense '-ing' form by adding 'ando' to 'estar'
For 'ir/er' verbs, you can construct future tense '-ing' form by adding 'iendo' to 'estar'
Estar implies states like location so we don't need to say 'there' (dondé) or 'here' (aquí)

examples.english: I'm there for you -> I'm for you
I'm here because of you (formal) -> I'm because of you
I have come because of you
It is because of you that we have come
examples.spanish: Es por ti que hemos venido

rules.rule: You can construct future tense 'would/could' form by adding 'ía' to the 'to' form verb. 'I' pronoun uses the same form as 'he', 'she', 'it', 'you' formal pronouns.

examples.english: I would eat but I don't have time
It would (get) transformed -> It would transform itself
I would imagine that (what) he doesn't want to go
examples.spanish: Me imaginaría que no quiere ir

examples.english: I would have been able to go out

rules.rule: Using -self form is common but it does not mean it changes the meaning

examples.english: I would imagine -> I would imagine myself

rules.rule: No tense words have no accent
'ar' verbs are the biggest group. New verbs adopt 'ar'
For nouns you can put 'a' ('una') or 'the' ('la') in front of it
For adjectives you can put 'is' ('es') in front of it
Adjectives are words that describe a word. Adjectives come after the noun they describe

examples.english: I want to buy a digital camera

rules.rule: Adjectives become plural when a noun is plural
Nouns can change genders but adjectives don't unless it ends in 'o'
Add 'es' to a (masculine/mixed) consonant word to get its plural version
Add 's' to a (feminine) consonant word to get its plural version
'The' (masculine) is 'El'. 'The' (feminine) is 'La'

examples.spanish: El coche (other ways to say car are: carro, auto, and machina)

rules.rule: 'The' (plural masculine) is 'Los'. 'The' (plural feminine) is 'Las'
'A' (masculine) is 'un'. 'A' (feminine) is 'una'

examples.spanish: Un coche (other ways to say car are: carro, auto, and machina)

rules.rule: Nouns have genders. The object itself does not have gender
Functional object words (pronouns) should come before conjugated verbs
Functional object words (pronouns) can come before or after 'to' form and '-ing' form verbs. Putting the pronoun before is more common.

examples.english: I'm taking a Spanish course -> I'm taking a course of Spanish
examples.spanish: Estoy tomando un curso de Espanõl

rules.rule: Functional subject words (pronouns) are flexible to be placed in the beginning, middle or end of a sentence. Depends on dialect and region

examples.english: Are you giving it to me tomorrow? (You give me it tomorrow?)
Are you giving it to me tomorrow? (You give me it tomorrow?)
Are you giving it to me tomorrow? (You give me it tomorrow?)

rules.rule: Pronoun direct object group: me, te, nos, lo/la, los/las
Pronoun indirect (to -'pronoun') object group: me, te, nos, le, les

examples.english: I am giving them something -> I am giving something to them
He is cooking me something -> He is cooking to me something
He is cooking them (feminine) something -> He is cooking to them (feminine) something
He is cooking them for us -> He is cooking them to us

rules.rule: Pronoun indirect ('pronoun' -self) object group: me, te, nos, se

examples.english: Are you staying? -> Are you remaining yourselve?
I want to stay -> I want to remain myself
He wants to stay -> He wants to remain himself
You guys want to stay -> You guys want to remain yourselves

rules.rule: Pronoun subject group: el, ella, tú, nosotros, nosotras, usted, yo, ellos, ellas

examples.english: Do you have time to talk?

rules.rule: Usted comes from 'Vuestra Merced' which means 'Your mercy'

examples.english: Do you know where to go

rules.rule: Feminine words end in 'a' or 'ion'
Words ending in 'ma' are masculine (which is an exception)

examples.english: The scheme (in Spanish, this means outline or diagram)

rules.rule: Words ending in 'ma' are usually of Greek origin. In Greek, these words are neutral.
Shortened words use their expanded version to identify its gender
Mano ('hand') is the only true 'o' word that is not shortened but is considered feminine

examples.english: Can you give me a hand? -> Are you able to give me a hand?
Could you give me a hand? -> Would you be able to give me a hand?
You should give me a hand -> You owe to give me a hand
You guys should give us a hand -> You guys owe to give us a hand

rules.rule: Use 'me' as 'myself' to express 'I got' or 'I get'

examples.english: I got lost / I've got lost (I lost myself)

rules.rule: Use 'te' as 'yourself' to express 'you got' or 'you get'

examples.english: You have got lost (You have lost yourself)

rules.rule: Use 'nos' as 'ourselves' to express 'we got' or 'we get'

examples.english: We have got lost (We have lost ourselves)

rules.rule: English words ending in -ive convert to -ivo for masculine versions. -iva for feminine versions.

examples.english: She is very creative but she is aggressive
examples.spanish: Ella es muy creativa pero es agresiva

rules.rule: There are only double r's and n's in spanish. The rest of the English words can omit duplicates
Words ending in '-ity' converts to '-idad'. These words are feminine
'ir' and 'er' verbs expand conjugation by using 'e' as its base. These words are historic and can have irregularity when conjugating
'ar' verbs expand conjugation by using 'a' as its base
Use 'a' to express '-ing' words before the 'to' form of a verb

examples.english: I am going out to eat
When are you coming to eat?

rules.rule: When repeating an expression after a conjunction, you can shorten it with 'si'

examples.english: I don't want to invite him but she wants to invite him (as in 'she does')
examples.spanish: Yo no tengo invitar lo pero ella si

rules.rule: The first 'e' in 'to' form present tense verbs typically will split as 'ie'
The first 'o' in 'to' form present tense verbs typically will split as 'ue'
A verb is used as a noun when 'a' or 'the' is in front of the word
Words starting in 'al' are typically from the Arabic language
If a words ends in a consonant, you add 'es' (not just 's')
You clarify saying 'you guys' as opposed to 'they/them' with ustedes

examples.english: Are you guys give it to us tomorrow? (You guys give us it tomorrow?)

rules.rule: Prepositions are usually built into the words such as me, te, and nos so they could be removed from the sentence. This can result in ambiguity so context needs to be accounted for

examples.english: They speak to me about it -> They speak me it
He buys it for me -> He buys me it
I buy it for you -> I buy you it
Shall I buy it for you? -> I buy you it?
Do you want to do it for me? -> You want to do me it?
I buy you something -> I buy 'for' you something
He buys it for me -> He buys me it
They buy them for me -> They buy those for me

rules.rule: Use pronoun verb + 'to' verb sentence structure to your advantage: voy (ir), doy (dar), puedo (poder), vengo (venir), quiero (querer), quedo (quedar), hago (hacer), he (haber), tengo (tener) qué, debo (deber), gusto (gustar), etc

examples.english: I can't find it (as opposed to I don't find it)
examples.spanish: No lo puedo encontrar (No lo encuentro)

examples.english: I am staying in the red car (I remain myself in the car red)
examples.spanish: Me quedo en el auto rojo

examples.english: I have stayed in the red car (I remained myself in the car red)
examples.spanish: Me he quedado en el auto rojo

examples.english: I have bought a red car (I bought a car red)
I have bought myself a red car (I bought myself a car red)
examples.spanish: Me he comprado un auto rojo

rules.rule: English words starting with 's' + consonant will usually have an 'e' in front of the Spanish version

examples.english: spanish, spain, student, school, special, strict, spectacular, state
examples.spanish: espanõl, españa, estudiante, escuela, especial, estricto, espectacular, estar

rules.rule: Voy, doy, estoy and soy are the only verbs that end with a 'oy'
Ellas/Ellos can be derived by pluralizing Ella
Usted is formal but ustedes is not. It is just a way to say 'you guys'
Some adjectives can be both stateful (estar) and a characteristic (ser)
De (from/of) comes from 'deliver' -> 'de liberar' -> 'liberation' -> 'set free' -> 'baby being born'

examples.english: Where is he from? (From where is he?) (characteristic)
Where is he from? (From where is he?) (characteristic/informal)
Where are they from? (From where are he?) (characteristic)
I am a free person (I am a person free) (characteristic)

rules.rule: v words in English are usually b in Spanish
Use 'Soy una persona (adjective)' to confirm a characteristic sentence when you don't know whether an adjective is flexible to assume both ser or estar.

examples.english: I am a free person -> I am a person free
examples.spanish: Soy libre -> Soy una persona libre
Soy una persona casado (or casada for feminine)

rules.rule: Adjectives can have different meanings depending on if it is used with ser or estar
Spanish words are either ser or estar based on the concept of the word. If forming a present tense estar sentence with a ser adjective, use the '-ing' form of ser to express 'being'

examples.english: Sincerity / Sincere (Sincerity is a characteristic. Therefore, sincere is also a characteristic)
I am being sincere (state + ser adjective)

rules.rule: Resist putting '-ing' into Spanish. That is only used for expressing present tense immediate

examples.english: I'm buying them -> I buy them
I'm buying them tomorrow -> I buy them tomorrow
I'm leaving soon -> I leave soon

rules.rule: Prepositions (words that establish relationship with upcoming noun or pronoun): para (for), de (from), con (with), etc
When a preposition is present, it is connected by a subject group pronoun instead of an object group pronoun

examples.english: I am having breakfast with them tomorrow -> I have breakfast with 'they' tomorrow
I am going to have breakfast with them tomorrow -> I go to breakfast with 'they' tomorrow
examples.spanish: Voy a desayunar con ellos mañana

rules.rule: When a preposition is present, if the subject group pronoun is me (yo) or you (usted/tú), they are replaced with 'mi' and 'ti' respectively
Para (For) is used when something is for somebody
Para (For) is used to express 'in order to ...'. In English 'in order to ...' can usually be omitted but in Spanish it is required.

examples.english: We have spoken in order to resolve it
We have spoken in order to try to resolve it
I'm here to see you -> I'm here in order to see you (informal)
I have called you (informal) to speak about it -> I have called you in order to speak it

rules.rule: Por (For) is used to express the phrase 'because of ...'

examples.english: Because of this reason I don't want to go
examples.spanish: Po esta razón no quiero ir

examples.english: I'm buying it because of you

rules.rule: Por (For) is used to express time durations

examples.english: I am staying for 3 days ->  I remain myself for 3 days
I will stay for 3 days -> I will remain myself for 3 days
I would stay for 3 days -> I would remain myself for 3 days

rules.rule: Por (For) is used to for exchaning this for that

examples.english: I would change this (masculine) one for that (masculine) one
I would change these (masculine) ones for those (masculine) ones
Would you (informal) change these (masculine) ones for those (masculine) ones?

rules.rule: Por (For) can be used as a multiplication symbol
Spanish may use different prepositions for certain expressions when compared with English

examples.english: I fall in love with you -> I fall in love of you
I am thinking about you -> I am thinking in/on you
examples.spanish: Pienso en ti / Estoy pensado en ti

examples.english: I dream of her -> I dream with her

rules.rule: If a verb comes after a preposition, the 'to' form of the verb is used

examples.english: It is a way of doing it
I don't believe in arguing in this way -> I don't believe in arguing of this way
examples.spanish: No creo en discutir de esta forma

rules.rule: Prepositions will not come at the end of sentences as they do in English

examples.english: Where are you from? -> From where are you?
Where are you going (to)? -> To where are you going? (informal)

rules.rule: You can add 'la' or 'el' to describe determiners

examples.english: The girl I work with -> The girl with which (determiner) I work
examples.spanish: La chica con la cúal trabajo

rules.rule: Determiners like 'which', 'that', and 'who' have their own words but can also use 'que'

examples.english: It is the girl I used to work with -> It is the girl with who I used to work
examples.spanish: Es la chica con que (quien) trabajaba

examples.english: Which one do you want? -> Which do you want?
I don't know which one he wants to do it with -> I don't know with which he wants to do it
examples.spanish: No sé con cuál (que) quiere hacerlo

examples.english: I don't know who I have to do it for -> I don't know for whom I have to do it
examples.spanish: No sé para quien (que) tengo que hacerlo

rules.rule: When using con with you or me, 'go' is added to the end of the word (ie. 'contigo' / 'conmigo')

examples.english: Do you want to come with me?
You have to come with me
I dream about you -> I dream with you

rules.rule: Future tense 'would be able to' = 'podría'. Due to long historic usage, what would be 'podería' is shortened to 'podría'

examples.english: Could you come to my house? -> Would you be able to come to my house?
Could you tell me something? -> Would you be able to tell me something?
Could you tell me if you want to come?
examples.spanish: Me podriás decir si quieres venir?

rules.rule: Future tense 'would have' = 'habría'. Due to long historic usage, what would be 'habería' is shortened to 'habría'

examples.english: We would have been able to go
They would have been able to eat
They would have come to eat
They would have liked it -> It would have pleased them
I would have liked it -> It would have pleased me
We would have liked them -> They would have pleased us

rules.rule: Future tense 'should' = 'would owe' = 'debería'

examples.english: You should come to my house -> You would owe to come to my house
You should come to my house to eat -> You would owe to come to my house to eat
examples.spanish: Deberías venir a mi casa a comer

examples.english: We should speak about it -> We would owe to speak it
We should speak to him -> We would owe to speak to him
We should speak to him -> We would owe to speak with he (less ambiguous)

rules.rule: Past tense 'had' = 'había'

examples.english: I had eaten already -> Already, I had eaten
He wanted to dine with me but I had dined already -> He wanted to dine with me but already, I had dined
examples.spanish: El quería cenar conmigo pero yo ya había cenado

rules.rule: Use line in the past ongoing action form if the verb is continuous and not an instant in the past

examples.english: He was looking for it because I had lost it
examples.spanish: El lo buscaba porque yo lo había perdido

examples.english: He wanted to dine with me but I had dined already -> He wanted to dine with me but already, I had dined
examples.spanish: El quería cenar conmigo pero yo ya había cenado

examples.english: I had got lost -> I had lost myself
I would have got lost -> I would have lost myself

rules.rule: Past tense complete point in the past: replace '-ar' with 'é' for I form or with 'ó' for he/she/it/you informal form.

examples.spanish: Me lo compró -> Lo compró para mi

examples.english: I didn't send it to you yet (informal)
It was sent yesterday -> It sent itself yesterday
I was going to do it but I forgot it
examples.spanish: Iba a hacerlo pero lo olvidé

rules.rule: Any form of haber (he, había, habría, habré, etc) will follow with the 'ado/ido' form of the verb

examples.english: I would like to have gone -> It would have pleased me to have gone

rules.rule: When using haber verbs as an adjective, haber is replaced with 'estar' (there are some exceptions)

examples.english: I have closed (the door 'la puerta') it
I get tired (verb) -> I tire myself
He is closed (verb) to the idea
He is a closed (adjective) person -> He is a person closed
It has got complicated (verb) -> It has complicated itself
I should have cancelled -> I should to have cancelled it
examples.spanish: Debería haberlo cancellado -> Lo debería haber cancellado

rules.rule: Irregular haber verbs: Romper (to break) is 'roto' with haber

examples.english: It has broken -> It has broken itself

rules.rule: Irregular haber verbs: Morir (to die) is 'muerto' with haber

examples.spanish: El está muerto (morir does not use ser)

examples.english: I die myself (I can't believe it / That is hilarious)

rules.rule: Irregular haber verbs: Abrir (to open) is 'abierto' with haber
Irregular haber verbs: Decir (to say) is 'dicho' with haber

examples.english: I have told them -> I have told to them

rules.rule: Irregular haber verbs: Hacer (to do) is 'hecho' with haber

examples.spanish: Lo debería haber hecho -> Debería haberlo hecho

examples.english: Made in China (It is done in China)

rules.rule: Este/Estos = This/These (masculine). Esta/Estas = This/These (feminine)
Ese/Esos = That/Those (masculine). Esa/Esas = That/Those (feminine)
If a verb naturally displays characteristics ('to be') in it's definition, mostly likely you will need to combine it with an indirect object pronoun group

examples.english: We like it -> It is pleasing to us
It interests me -> It is interesting to me
Does it interest her to dance tonight?
Would it interest you -> Would it be interesting to you (formal)
It would interest me to see it -> It would be interesting to me to see it

rules.rule: Append 'a' to in between verbs that express motion

examples.english: Does it interest her to go out to dance tonight?
examples.spanish: Le interesa 'salir a' bailar esta noche

examples.english: It seems to me that he doesn't want to go out tonight
examples.spanish: Me parese que no quiere 'salir' esta noche

rules.rule: Days of the week refer to planets
'Lo [word]' = 'The [word] thing'

examples.english: The interesting thing is that they live together
examples.spanish: Lo interesante es que vivin juntos

rules.rule: 'Lo de' = 'The thing about' (very common)

examples.english: We are speaking about the thing about the party
examples.spanish: Hablamos sobre lo de la fiesta

examples.english: I don't want to speak about Juan's business like this -> I don't want to speak of the thing about Juan like this
examples.spanish: No quiero hablar de lo de Juan asi

rules.rule: 'Asi' = 'Like this' or 'Like that' (very common). This replaces phrases like 'in that way' or 'in this manner'

examples.english: We don't speak in this (of that) way -> We don't speak like this
examples.spanish: No hablamos de esa forma -> No hablamos asi

examples.english: I don't want to organize it like this
